title: CTRL0000050106 - Transcribed Interview of James DeGraffenreid, (February 24, 2022)

data.text: SELECT COMMITTEE TO INVESTIGATE THE
JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL,
U.S. HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES,
WASHINGTON, D.C.
DEPOSITION OF:
JAMES DEGRAFFENREID
Thursday, February 24, 2022
Washington, D.C.
The deposition in the above matter was held via Webex, commencing at 2:12 p.m.
Appearances:
For the SELECT COMMITTEE TO INVESTIGATE
THE JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL:
STAFF ASSOCIATE
CHIEF CLERK
, INVESTIGATIVE COUNSEL
PROFESSIONAL STAFF MEMBER
OF COUNSEL TO THE VICE CHAIR
For THE WITNESS:
GEORGE KELESIS
BRIAN HARDY
We are now on the record.
It is 2:12 p.m. Eastern on February 24, 2022.
This is the deposition of Mr. James
DeGraffenreid, conducted by the House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th
Attack on the United States Capitol, pursuant to House Resolution 503.
At this time, I'd like to ask Mr. DeGraffenreid to please state his full name and to
spell his last name for the record.
The Witness.
My full name is James Walter DeGraffenreid,
D-e-G-r-a-f-f-e-n-r-e-i-d.
Thank you, Mr. DeGraffenreid.
This will be a staff-led interview.
My name is
and I am an investigative counsel for the Select Committee.
I am joined here today b y - w h o is Senior Investigative Counsel for the Select
Committee, and also serves as of counsel to the Vice Chair, Representative Liz Cheney.
Also in the room is
who is professional staff for the Select Committee.
Members of the Select Committee may be joining us and leaving during the course
of our discussion, and if any of them so choose they, of course, may ask questions as well.
I'll do my best to announce for the record whenever they join, but right now I don't
believe that any of them are here with us.
At this time, would Mr. DeGraffenreid's counsel please state their names for the
record.
Mr. Kelesis.
This is George Kelesis.
Mr. Hardy.
This is Brian Hardy with the law firm of Marquis Aurbach on behalf of
Mr. DeGraffenreid.
I am Mr. DeGraffenreid's personal counsel.
Thank you.
So at this time, I'd like to ask the court reporter to please administer the oath to
Mr. DeGraffenreid.
The Reporter.
Do you solemnly declare and affirm under the penalty of perjury
that the testimony you are about to give will be the truth, the whole truth, and nothing
but the truth?
The Witness.
Thank you.
I do.
Before we begin, I'd like to cover a few ground rules.
So, as you saw, Mr.
DeGraffenreid, there is an official reporter who is transcribing the record of this
interview.
You and your attorneys will have an opportunity to review the transcript and
suggest any corrections before it's finalized.
being videotaped and audio recorded, but I will note that the court reporter's transcript is
the official record of the proceeding.
And, as I'm sure you can also tell, this is
Because this is being transcribed, we ask that you wait until each question is
completed before you begin your response and, likewise, we will try and wait until your
responses are completed before we ask our next question.
that the transcript of the record is as complete and accurate as possible.
That just helps us ensure
The stenographer cannot record nonverbal responses, such as shaking your head
or saying uh-huh, so it's important that you answer each question with an audible verbal
response, yes, no, I don't know.
I want to make sure that you understand that you're appearing pursuant to a
subpoena from the Select Committee dated January 28, 2022, which is in the materials
that have been provided to your counsel, and will be included in the record.
As you know, you are under oath, meaning that any knowing false statement that
you make today can constitute perjury as well as a violation of 18 United States Code
So it's important that you tell the truth at all times.
It's, of course, important that you understand our questions and are able to
answer them to the best of your ability.
So, to that end, please don't hesitate to ask us
to repeat a question if it's not clear, or if you don't understand.
Similarly, if you don't know the answer to a question, you can say you don't know
or that you don't recall, but keep in mind that you're under oath and you have to be
truthful.
So if you do recall the answer to a question, you must say so.
If you need to consult with your counsel at any time during the interview, that is
certainly no problem.
We can disable the camera and place the audio on mute so that
you can converse with your counsel as needed.
necessary.
So please just let us know if that's ever
And if you need a break for any other reason during the interview, please let us
know.
I'll also try and make sure that we take regular short breaks during the course of
our conversation.
Do you have any questions for us before we begin?
The Witness.
I do not.
Thank you.
So I will begin by directing your attention to exhibit 40, which we will show
Q
you on the screen.
Mr. Hardy. - c a n we just make sure that on the record today, that we're
clear, similar to what we did before, that you understand that we're seeking to preserve
the attorney-client privilege and any questions you ask are not intended to seek
attorney-client information?
Absolutely.
Mr. Hardy.
Perfect.
Yeah.
Thank you, Brian.
BY
Then we're good and we can proceed forward.
Q
All right.
So on the screen I hope you can see, Mr. DeGraffenreid, this is a
letter from the chairman, Benny Thompson, dated January 28, 2022, addressed to you.
Is this a copy of the subpoena that you received from the select committee, as far
as you can tell?
A
As far as I can tell from what is shown, yes, it is.
Q
And do you understand that you are appearing here today pursuant to the
subpoena with your name, Mr. James DeGraffenreid, on it?
A
Yes, I do.
Q
Part of the subpoena required you to produce documents and information,
including electronically stored information.
Do you understand that?
A
I do understand that.
Q
And did you search for records that are responsive to the subpoena
schedule?
A
Yes, I did.
Q
Have you produced to the select committee all the documents and
communications in your possession, custody, or control that are responsive to the
requests in the subpoena?
A
To the best of my knowledge, I have, yes.
Q
I'll ask a few questions just to get a sense of that.
But did you search your
personal devices for responsive information, including your laptop, phone, or any other
devices?
A
Yes, I did.
Q
Did you use any secured messaging applications on any of your personal
devices, and by that, I mean applications like Signal, Telegram or WhatsApp -- and, if so,
have you searched for and produced any responsive materials from those applications?
A
I did use those applications, and I believe you saw from what was submitted
that I did submit that responsive information.
Q
Did you have any devices or email accounts that you used in an official
capacity, for example, from the Nevada GOP and, if so, have you searched for and
produced any responsive materials?
A
Can you please repeat that question?
Q
Sure.
So did you have any devices or email accounts that you used in an
official capacity, for example, a Nevada GOP email account, or a laptop that was provided
to you by the Nevada GOP, and, if so, did you search those devices and accounts for
responsive information?
A
I do have an email
account, and I did search that account.
I had no devices provided to me by the Nevada GOP.
Q
Did you keep any handwritten or electronic notes and, if so, did you search
those for responsive materials?
A
I don't recall any handwritten notes.
Q
Did you have any involvement in tweets that are put out by the Nevada GOP
Twitter account?
A
Anything that I would have had, I did
search.
On occasion, before tweets go out, they are circulated to the leadership of
the party to review.
Q
And do you typically provide input on those tweets whenever you see them?
A
Occasionally.
Q
Understood.
Did you coordinate with any person other than your
attorneys, or your attorneys' sort of administrative staff in responding to the document
requests in the subpoena?
A
I did not.
Q
All right.
So, to start, Mr. DeGraffenreid, I'd appreciate if you could briefly
summarize your professional background, starting with any schooling and then leading up
to today.
A
California in 1980.
For the last 20 years I have been a firefighter/EMT for Mono County Fire Rescue.
own a small business, an insurance agency in Minden, Nevada, with my wife.
have been involved in the Nevada GOP since approximately 2008.
Okay.
I graduated high school from Mayfair High School in Lakewood,
I attended some college, did not obtain a degree from any college.
I also
And then I
Q
Do you have an official role in the Nevada GOP?
A
I am currently the Republican National Committeeman for the State of
Nevada.
Q
And have you held that role since 2008, or has your title or your capacity
changed over the years?
A
My capacity has changed.
I was originally just a member of the party.
have been the Republican National Committeeman since 2020.
Q
Understood.
Did you have any formal role in either the 2016 or 2020
Trump Presidential campaigns and, if so, please describe what those formal
responsibilities were?
A
I didn't have any formal responsibilities relative to the campaign itself.
During the 2016 campaign, I was the vice chairman of the State party.
In that role, our
job is to identify voters, register voters, turn them out to vote, basically support the
campaigns of all Republican candidates in the State.
connection with my role as vice chairman of the party.
Q
All right.
And so, I did those things in
Just to make sure that I understand clearly, so you've held a role
as National Committeeman and you've also held a role as vice chair of the State party at
some point in time?
A
That is correct.
Q
Thank you.
Prior to that, Secretary of the party, if it's relevant.
What were your sort of informal responsibilities on either of
those campaigns in your capacity as vice chair of the State GOP?
A
There was probably nothing specific to the Trump campaign.
Again, my
role was to support all Republican candidates in the State.
role is primarily organizational, taking care of planning State party meetings and
conventions and that sort of thing.
voters for the election.
Q
And so, the vice chairman's
As I said, working -- working to identify and turn out
So I'd like to shift over to the topic of the 2020 Presidential election.
In,
let's say, after the Presidential election in 2020, so starting on November 3rd and in the
weeks thereafter, Mr. DeGraffenreid, did you participate in any conversations with any
individuals from the Trump campaign, the Trump White House, or the RNC about their
response to the Presidential election results?
A
Upon advice of counsel, I am asserting my rights under Article I, Section 8 of
the Nevada Constitution and the Fifth Amendment to the United States Constitution.
The United States Supreme Court has long held that constitutional protections
against self-incrimination were designed to protect the innocent as well as the guilty.
The Supreme Court has also recognized that one of the basic functions of the privilege is
to protect innocent men, and has firmly rejected the view that any adverse assumptions
or implications of guilt should be drawn about anyone who exercises these cherished
constitutional rights.
Accordingly, upon advice of counsel, I expressly decline to answer your question.
Q
Thank you, Mr. DeGraffenreid.
And, of course, you are entitled to assert
your constitutional privileges under the Fifth Amendment.
We have communicated this previously to your counsel, but just so that you and I
are clear on how we'll proceed from here, we will continue to ask you questions.
any point when you wish to assert your Fifth Amendment privileges, you may do so in
response to a question.
Please do not feel as if you have to recite the entirety of what you just read each
time.
assert a Fifth Amendment privilege, that's perfectly all right.
If there is some shorthand that you'd like to refer to any time that you'd like to
A
I understand.
Q
Thank you.
And at
So, with that, I will go ahead and move to the topic of Trump
Presidential electors in the 2020 Presidential election.
Mr. DeGraffenreid, can you describe your understanding of the concept of
alternate electors as it relates to the 2020 Presidential election?
A
As stated previously, I expressly decline to answer your question under the
rights previously asserted.
Q
Were you aware of a plan to convene alternate electors in Michigan,
Pennsylvania, Wisconsin, New Mexico, Georgia, Nevada or Arizona to cast electoral votes
for President Trump and Vice President Pence?
A
Under advice of counsel, I assert the previous privilege.
Q
When did you first become aware of a plan related to alternate electors in
the 2020 election, and who first told you about it?
A
Under advice of counsel, I assert the previous privilege.
Q
In your understanding, why was it necessary for alternate electors to
convene in these States?
A
Under advice of counsel, I assert the prior privilege.
Q
Did you participate in a meeting of alternate electors that took place in
Carson City, Nevada, on December 14, 2020, to cast electoral ballots for President Trump
and Vice President Pence?
A
Under advice of counsel, I assert the prior privilege.
Q
To your knowledge, who was involved in coordinating that ceremony from
either the Trump campaign, Trump legal team, Trump White House, or RNC?
A
Under advice of counsel, I assert the prior privilege.
Q
I am going to ask you about your communications with a number of
individuals regarding plans to convene an alternate set of electors.
you don't have to assert the privilege each time that I say a name, I will simply read the
list of names to you and you can respond as you see fit.
And for your sake so
So my question is, did you have any communications with any of the following
Trump campaign officials regarding plans to convene an alternate set of electors for
Nevada:
Chesebro, James Troupis, John Eastman, Boris Epshteyn, Bernard Kerik, Mike Roman or
Mike Brown?
Rudy Giuliani, Jenna Ellis, Matt Morgan, Justin Clark, Nick Trainer, Kenneth
A
Under advice of counsel, I assert the prior privilege.
Q
Did you have any communications with any of the following Trump White
House officials regarding plans to convene an alternate set of electors:
Trump, Mark Meadows, or any other member of the administration?
President
A
Under advice of counsel, I assert the prior privilege.
Q
Were you aware of any coordination of alternate elector ceremonies across
multiple States?
And when I say multiple States during the course of today's deposition,
I mean Michigan, Pennsylvania, Wisconsin, New Mexico, Georgia, Nevada or Arizona.
A
Under advice of counsel, I assert the prior privilege.
Q
Mr. DeGraffenreid, I'd like to direct your attention to the document in
exhibit 5.
conversation dated October 30, 2020, between you and Mr. Shawn Meehan.
This is a document ending with Bates 591, and it appears to be a text message
Do you recognize this conversation?
A
Under advice of counsel, I assert the prior privilege.
Q
In this exchange at 4:30 p.m., it looks like Mr. Meehan wrote the following,
quote:
see Sisolak submitting one slate and Barbara having to send our slate.
controversial situations, I wonder how that plays out."
"Been reading more on Electoral College.
Then you responded, quote:
If things get really sorted up, I could
As she dislikes
"Elder might do a lot of things, but sending a slate
of Republican electors without them being clearly the winners of the popular vote is not
one of them."
Was this the first time that you had heard someone discuss sending competing
slates of electors in the event that President Trump didn't win the election in Nevada?
A
Under advice of counsel, I assert the prior privilege.
Q
It appears to me that this exchange took place before Election Day on
November 3rd.
President Trump had won Nevada or not?
Why was this strategy the topic of discussion before you knew whether
A
Under advice of counsel, I assert the prior privilege.
Q
So next, I'll direct your attention to exhibit 6.
Bates 544.
November 29, 2020.
This is a document ending in
This appears to be an exchange between you and Mr. Meehan dated
And Mr. Meehan wrote, quote:
"And we have a template for when we complete
ours and send it in ourselves when Sisolak refuses," unquote, referring to a certificate of
ascertainment, as discussed in your prior text message.
At this time, November 29th, was there a plan in place to prepare an alternate
certificate of ascertainment for President Trump's Nevada electors?
A
On the advice of counsel, I assert the prior privilege.
Q
Around this time, were you aware of any discussions involving the Trump
administration, Trump campaign, or RNC related to this scenario?
A
Under advice of counsel, I assert the prior privilege.
Q
We will discuss this in more detail shortly, but is it correct that you and the
other Trump electors in Nevada had filed a lawsuit in State Court related to the 2020
Presidential election results?
A
Under advice of counsel, I assert the prior privilege.
Q
Did you participate in any calls or meetings with anyone from the Trump
administration, Trump campaign, or RNC related to that litigation?
A
Under advice of counsel, I assert the prior privilege.
Q
Were you part of a discussion on December 8, 2020, related to alternate
electors?
A
Under advice of counsel, I assert the prior privilege.
Q
Did anyone from the Trump administration, Trump campaign, or RNC
participate in that discussion?
A
Under advice of counsel, I assert the prior privilege.
Q
So next I'd like to turn to exhibit 7, which is a document ending in Bates
number 634.
While we pull it up, I will describe to you that this is a message exchange
between you, Mr. Meehan, and Jim Hindle dated December 9, 2020.
And you wrote
below this message that's on the screen the following, quote:
"And we need to also
decide if we're sending in our own ballot.
Congressman will make the objection ... Cruz and Jordan maybe."
Need to know which Senator and
Scroll down.
Was there a discussion at this time related to the submission of alternate electoral
ballots and, if so, among whom?
A
Under advice of counsel, I assert the prior privilege.
Q
Was the alternate elector plan contingent in any way upon the objection of a
House Member and a Senator during the certification on January 6th?
A
Under advice of counsel, I assert the prior privilege.
Q
And if you could scroll d o w n , _
Later in this exchange, you wrote, quote:
clearly communicated last evening.
"Yes, the elector frustration was
Crystal clearly."
What frustration were you referring to in this message?
A
Under advice of counsel, I assert the prior privilege.
Q
Then below, you wrote the following, quote:
consider and plan."
"So we have some time to
Could you please scroll down.
What were the relevant considerations in deciding to move forward with sending
alternate electoral ballots?
A
Under advice of counsel, I assert the prior privilege.
Q
Next, I'd like to direct your attention to exhibit 16.
This is a Bates ending in
631, and I believe that it is another version of the message exchange that we were just
discussing.
This is dated December 9th, and it's between you, Mr. Meehan, and Mr. Hindle,
and in it, you write, quote:
in mind to have the electors meet in Carson City Monday to cast our ballots and transmit
to the Senate."
"Online with legal right now.
Attorneys and campaign have
Did you participate in a call on December 9th with members of the campaign to
discuss this issue?
A
On advice of counsel, I assert the prior privilege.
Q
Your message that we just discussed suggests to me that there had not yet
been a decision made regarding alternate electors at that time.
that and this message?
What changed between
A
On advice of counsel, I assert the prior privilege.
Q
In your understanding, what was the basis for the campaign's plan for you to
cast your ballots?
A
On advice of counsel, I assert the prior privilege.
Q
Next, I'll direct your attention to exhibit 8.
This is a document with Bates
ending in 774, and I'll describe to you that it is a December 10, 2020, email exchange from
an individual named Kenneth Chesebro to you, Mr. Michael McDonald, Mr. Jesse Law,
and it says the following, quote:
campaign (including Justin Clark and Nick Trainer) asked me to reach out to you and the
other Nevada electors to run point on the plan to have all Trump-Pence electors in all six
contested States meet and transmit their votes to Congress on Monday, December 14."
"Mayor Giuliani and others with the Trump-Pence
Who, if you know, is Kenneth Chesebro?
A
Under advice of counsel, I assert the prior privilege.
Q
What was Mr. Chesebro's connection to Mr. Giuliani, Mr. Clark, and
Mr. Trainer, if you know?
A
Under advice of counsel, I assert the prior privilege.
Q
If you know, how were Mr. Giuliani, Mr. Clark, and Mr. Trainer involved in
the efforts relating to alternate electors?
A
Under advice of counsel, I assert the prior privilege.
Q
Do you know why Mr. Chesebro was reaching out to you, Mr. McDonald, and
Mr. Law, regarding this issue?
A
Under advice of counsel, I assert the prior privilege.
Q
In his email, Mr. Chesebro wrote that he was contacting you and the other
Nevada electors, quote, "to run point on the plan to have all Trump-Pence electors in all
six contested States meet."
That suggests to me that you were already somewhat familiar with this idea.
that accurate?
A
Under advice of counsel, I assert the prior privilege.
Q
Other than the communications we've already discussed, what other
Is
conversations or communications did you have regarding the alternate electors plan with
any member of the RNC Trump campaign or Trump administration?
A
Under advice of counsel, I assert the prior privilege.
Q
Did you ever have any direct contact with Mr. Giuliani, Mr. Clark, or
Mr. Trainer, related to alternate electors?
A
Under advice of counsel, I assert the prior privilege.
Q
At the end of his email, Mr. Chesebro contains -- or includes, rather, a draft
press release that was slated for release as part of Wisconsin litigation.
It's at the end of
the email and it's titled "Proposed Jim Troupis Statement on Electors' Meeting."
Do you know who Jim Troupis is?
A
Under advice of counsel, I assert the prior privilege.
Q
The last paragraph of that release contains the following, quote:
"Given
that the results in Wisconsin are still in doubt, with legal arguments that have yet to be
decided ... so, too, the Republican electors should meet this year on December 14 as we
await a final resolution in Wisconsin."
What did you understand this language in the press release to mean?
A
Under advice of counsel, I assert the prior privilege.
Q
And how did you think that guidance applied to your situation in Nevada?
A
Under advice of counsel, I assert the prior privilege.
Q
Was it your understanding that this guidance suggested that alternate
electors were appropriate because litigation was ongoing in your State?
A
Under advice of counsel, I assert the prior privilege.
Q
And did you understand Mr. Chesebro's guidance here to mean that
alternate electors were justified because the results in your State were, quote, "still in
doubt"?
A
Under advice of counsel, I assert the prior privilege.
Q
All right.
So after receiving this email, it looks like you forwarded it on
December 10th at 4 p.m. to Mr. Hindle, Mr. Law, and Mr. McDonald, as well as Jesse
Binall, and you wrote, quote:
"What do we know about Ken?
Is this a legit outreach?"
What was your understanding of Mr. Chesebro's relationship to the campaign at
that time?
A
Under advice of counsel, I assert the prior privilege.
Q
Did you ever learn more information about that?
A
Under advice of counsel, I assert the prior privilege.
Q
Mr. Binall then responded to your email and wrote, quote:
Without divulging the contents of any privileged communications, are you aware
of any further steps that Mr. Bina II took on this issue?
"I'll handle."
A
On advice of counsel, I assert the prior privilege.
Q
So next, let's take a look at exhibit 9 with Bates number ending in 761.
This
is a December 11th and 12th email exchange that starts with Mr. Chesebro emailing a
number of individuals whose email addresses indicate that they were affiliated with
either the Trump campaign or the GOP.
you on December 12th.
And then later, it looks like it was forwarded to
And in Mr. Chesebro's original message, he wrote, quote:
"As mentioned to
Mike Brown (who I am now copying on this thread), I was in email communication with
Jim DeGraffenreid a couple of days ago, and he was very responsive."
Do you know how the recipients on this initial email were involved in coordinating
alternate electors, if at all?
A
On advice of counsel, I assert the prior privilege.
Q
Mr. Chesebro, in this email, mentioned communication with you a couple of
days ago.
communication earlier?
Was that communication the email on December 10th or some other
A
On advice of counsel, I assert the prior privilege.
Q
An individual named Jeremy Hughes then forwarded that message to
Mr. McDonald, you, and Jessica Hanson and wrote, quote:
connected.
"Sounds like you all
Feel like everything is good?"
What was your relationship with Mr. Hughes?
A
On advice of counsel, I assert the prior privilege.
Q
Had you two been in contact previously about alternate elector issues?
A
On advice of counsel, I assert the prior privilege.
Q
So attached to Mr. Chesebro's initial email are I count seven documents, one
of which I'd like to cover right now.
That contains Bates number 762 and it's just further
down in the same exhibit.
It's a document that is titled "How to Cast Electoral Votes in Nevada."
like it contains a number of instructions about meeting, convening the ceremony, et
cetera.
It looks
Was this essentially the guide that you followed when planning for the signing
ceremony?
A
On advice of counsel, I assert the prior privilege.
Q
On the fifth page of this exhibit, there is a section titled "Draft language for
NV Republican Party re:
December 14 casting of electoral votes," and it contains the
following language in the last paragraph:
doubt, with legal arguments that have yet to be decided ... so too the Republican electors
should meet this year on December 14 as we await a final resolution of Nevada's six
electoral votes."
"Given that the results in Nevada are still in
Was this consistent with your understanding of the purpose of alternate electors?
A
On advice of counsel, I assert the prior privilege.
Q
In your understanding, were the election results in Nevada, quote, "still in
doubt" and, if so, how?
A
On advice of counsel, I assert the prior privilege.
Q
All right.
Related to these documents, I'd like to ask a few questions about
the guidance that you received about the legality of the elector ceremony.
Did you ever have any discussions related to any legal issues surrounding an
alternate elector ceremony?
And, again, I remind you that I'm asking you to answer
without divulging any attorney-client privileged information.
A
On advice of counsel, I assert the prior privilege.
Q
In your understanding, were there any key issues or concerns related to how
the ceremony was supposed to be conducted?
A
On advice of counsel, I assert the prior privilege.
Q
Did anyone provide you with any documentation or legal reasoning to
support this understanding of the law?
A
On advice of counsel, I assert the prior privilege.
Q
In any of these discussions, did you discuss Nevada's State laws regarding
the appointment of Presidential and Vice Presidential electors?
A
On advice of counsel, I assert the prior privilege.
Q
Were you aware of any concerns about whether such a ceremony was
allowed under State law?
A
On advice of counsel, I assert the prior privilege.
Q
Were you aware at that time that Nevada State law requires electors to
meet in the presence of the secretary of state?
A
On advice of counsel, I assert the prior privilege.
Q
At the time, were you aware that Nevada State law requires electors to
commit to voting for the popular vote winner in the State?
A
On advice of counsel, I assert the prior privilege.
Q
Did you have any discussions or receive any guidance as to how those State
laws would affect the alternate elector ceremony, if at all?
A
On advice of counsel, I assert the prior privilege.
Q
Was it your understanding that it was lawful to proceed with the alternate
elector ceremony in spite of these concerns and, if so, why?
A
On advice of counsel, I assert the prior privilege.
Q
Next, I'll direct your attention to exhibit 10, which ends in Bates number 746.
This is a memorandum from Mr. Chesebro addressed to Mr. Troupis dated November 18,
2020, although it's characterized as a December 10th streamlined revision, and the title is
"Regarding the Real Deadline for Settling a State's Electoral Votes."
Did you read this memorandum before the alternate elector ceremony on
December 14th?
A
On advice of counsel, I assert the prior privilege.
Q
I'll direct you to the second page of this document, which is under the
header, quote, "What Must Happen on December 14."
And the second paragraph of
that reads:
and Pence meet and cast their votes on December 14.
electors pledged to Trump and Pence might meet and cast their votes on December 14
even if, at that juncture, the Trump-Pence ticket is behind in the vote count, and no
certificate of election has been issued in favor of Trump and Pence.
reading of the Federal statutes suggests that this is a reasonable course of action."
Prudence dictates that the electors in each State who are pledged to Trump
It may seem odd that the
However, a fair
What was your understanding of the guidance provided in this memorandum?
A
On advice of counsel, I assert the prior privilege.
Q
On the basis of this guidance, was your understanding that an alternate
elector ceremony was a prudential or reasonable course of action to take?
A
On advice of counsel, I assert the prior privilege.
